children.name: Overview
children.description:
First Paragraph

The cell is the fundamental unit of life, serving as the building block for all organisms. Although all cells have some basic parts, different types of cells have evolved over time. There are two major categories of cells, prokaryotic cells and eukaryotic cells, that differ in their structural organization. Whereas prokaryotic cells have a simple structure, eukaryotic cells have several types of membrane-bound organelles and a nucleus. Animal and plant cells are two types of eukaryotic cell that each have some distinctive components.

children.at_a_glance:
• All organisms are made of cells. Some test
  • All cells have the same basic structures: a plasma membrane, cytoplasm, ribosomes, and DNA.
  • Prokaryotic cells and eukaryotic cells differ in their size and structure, but share some common structural organization.
  • Prokaryotic cells have additional components that aid in movement, reproduction, and support of the cell.
  • Eukaryotes are a type of cell containing a nucleus and other membrane-bound organelles.
  • Major features of eukaryotic cells are organelles, or structures that perform specific functions for the cell, and a complex system of membranes called the endomembrane system.
  • Major features of eukaryotic cells are organelles, the cytoskeleton, and a complex system of membranes called the endomembrane system.
  • Eukaryotes can be further divided into plant and animal cells that have some key differences, such as cell walls, chloroplasts, and large central vacuoles

children.name: What Are Cells?
children.summary_point: All organisms are made of cells.
children.body:
All organisms, from a tiny amoeba to a giant blue whale, are made of cells. Most cells are so small that they and can only be seen through a microscope. Yet, each cell carries out a multitude of processes that make life possible, such as the extraction of energy from food and the construction of proteins. Some organisms, such as a bacterium, are made up of just a single cell (unicellular). Other organisms, such as plants or animals, are composed of many cells (multicellular) that collectively support the functions necessary for life. These multicellular organisms often have different cell types, such as muscle and nerve cells, that do different jobs.


Some text with subscript1 and superscript2

chloroplast

images.path: Cell Types and Structures (Keep this valid)/Content/3385732.svg

children.name: Basic Cellular Components
children.summary_point: All cells have the same basic structures: a plasma membrane, cytoplasm, ribosomes, and DNA.
children.body:
The plasma membrane is a boundary that separates the cell interior from the external environment and regulates substances that cross into and out of the cell. The membrane is made up of molecules called phospholipids, each composed of a phosphate-containing “head” and two fatty acid “tails.” The phospholipids are arranged in two layers, together called a phospholipid bilayer. The phosphate heads in each layer are hydrophilic (“water-loving”) and thus face outward because they are attracted to water on each side of the membrane. The fatty acid tails are hydrophobic (“water-fearing”) and face inward towards each other to avoid water. This structure allows nonpolar molecules (which lack a charge) to pass easily through the hydrophobic interior of the membrane, but acts as a barrier to polar molecules and ions (which have a charge). Several types of proteins are also interspersed within the bilayer, some of which help regulate the passage of charged substances (such as water) across the hydrophobic membrane interior. The phospholipid bilayer is the basic structure of all biological membranes, including those that encompass some internal cellular structures.

Cytoplasm is material between the plasma membrane and nucleoid (prokaryotes) or nucleus (eukaryotes). This includes a thick fluid, called cytosol, containing water and dissolved substances. Cytoplasm also includes components suspended in the cytosol, such as organelles and ribosomes.

Ribosomes are particles where proteins are constructed. Each ribosome consists of two subunits composed of ribosomal RNA and protein. “Free” ribosomes are suspended in cytosol and make proteins that remain in cellular fluid. Other ribosomes compose part of an organelle called the rough endoplasmic reticulum and make proteins that become part of membranes or are secreted from the cell.

DNA is the hereditary material of the cell that serves as the blueprint for protein construction. Most DNA is organized with proteins into structures called chromosomes.

children.caption: Caption

children.name: Organelles
children.body:
Eukaryotic cells have the basic cellular components, as well as the following organelles:
  • The nucleus is an organelle surrounded by a double-membrane that contains one or more chromosomes (collectively called chromatin). A structure within the nucleus, called the nucleolus, is involved in the construction of ribosomal subunits.
  • Mitochondria are the sites of cellular respiration, the process of extracting chemical energy from organic molecules (food) and storing it as ATP. Mitochondria are often regarded as the “powerhouses” of the cell.
  • Peroxisomes contain enzymes that transfer oxygen from various molecules to hydrogen, producing hydrogen peroxide (H2O2) as a byproduct. They serve various functions, including detoxifying alcohol and breaking down fatty acids.

children.name: The Endomembrane System
children.body:
All eukaryotic cells also contain a collection of membranes, called the endomembrane system, that are involved in the manufacture and transport of molecules, as well as other functions. The endomembrane system is composed of the nuclear envelope and several membranous organelles.
  • The endoplasmic reticulum (ER) is a series of tubes and sacs that comprise the rough ER and smooth ER. The rough ER contains ribosomes, making the surface appear “rough”. The ribosomes construct proteins that are either incorporated into membranes or secreted outside the cell. The smooth ER lacks ribosomes and is involved in the synthesis of lipids (such as phospholipids, cholesterol, and steroid hormones) and the detoxification of drugs. Products of the ER that are destined for transport are packaged in membrane-bound compartments, called transport vesicles. Some vesicles are sent to the Golgi apparatus for further processing.
  • The Golgi apparatus is composed of stacks of flattened membrane and acts like a “shipping center” for the cell. Vesicles arriving from the ER merge with one side of the Golgi membrane, called the cis face, and drop off the molecules they contain. The molecules are then chemically modified, moved into transport vesicles on the other side of the Golgi (the trans face), and shipped to their final destinations within the cell or to the cell exterior. The Golgi adds chemical tags that act as “address labels” to the exported molecules so that they travel to the correct place.
  • Vacuoles are vesicles arising from the ER, Golgi apparatus, or plasma membrane. They serve several functions and vary in size. For instance, some protists engulf their food and encircle it with a plasma membrane. This process creates a food vacuole used for digestion. Plant cells have a large central vacuole that stores a variety of substances (see below).

Lysosomes are sacs containing digestive enzymes that break down large molecules. Some lysosome function to digest food in protists. These unicellular organisms engulf their food, forming food vacuoles. Lysosomes merge with the food vacuoles to digest the food they contain. Other lysosomes break down damaged organelles so that their components can be recycled. They are found in most animal cells and in some plant cells.

children.name: Parts Involved in Cell Shape and Movement
children.header: Parts Involved in Cell Shape and Movement
children.body:
Eukaryotic cells have a lattice of protein fibers, called the cytoskeleton, that supports the cell and assists in cell motility. It is composed of three kinds of fibers: microfilaments, intermediate filaments, and microtubules. Microfilaments (also called actin filaments) are involved in changes in cell shape, such as those that enable an amoeba to move. Intermediate filaments maintain cell shape and keep organelles in place. Microtubules form “tracks” that guide the movement of organelles and chromosomes within the cell. In animal cells, microtubules originate from a region of the cell called the centrosome. They cytoskeleton is dynamic, as its fibers can be broken down or built up where needed.

Microtubules compose two types of projections used for motility in some eukaryotic cells: flagella and cilia. Some aquatic protists and most sperm cells have a flagellum, a long projection made of microtubules that propels the cell through liquid in an undulating motion (note that flagella of eukaryotic cells are structurally different from those of prokaryotes). Other aquatic protists are covered with cilia (singular: cilium), small projections that move like oars of a rowboat to propel the cell forward. Cilia are also found on cells of tissues that move substances across their surfaces. For example, the cilia of cells lining the windpipe help expel mucus from the lungs.

course.name: Introduction to Biology (Dev)
course.subject: Science
course.description: Introduction to Biology commonly covers a broad range of biology concepts for entry level biology students. Course concepts often include cells, evolution, genetics, and plant and animal life.
course.meta_description: This study guide and infographic for George Orwell’s 1984 offer summary and analysis on themes, symbols, and other literary devices found in the text.
